video.title_en: Why is Halley's Comet so famous?

summary.text_en: Edmond Halley, Newton's friend and the financier of his 'Principia', published his 'Synopsis of the Astronomy of Comets' in 1705. He was the first person to apply Newton's new laws of gravity (`newton_gravity_1687`) to comets. After laborious calculations, he noticed the orbits of comets seen in 1531, 1607, and 1682 were remarkably similar. He made the bold hypothesis that these were not three separate comets, but the *same comet* on a giant elliptical path. He then made a stunning scientific prediction: the comet would return in late **1758**.
key_points_en: First application of Newton's laws to comets
Proved comets were predictable members of the solar system
First great triumph of Newton's theory

story.text_en: It was Halley who visited Newton in 1684 and asked him what orbit an inverse-square force would produce. Newton's reply ('an ellipse') and his admission that he had already calculated it, stunned Halley. Halley immediately paid for and managed the publication of Newton's 'Principia' (`newton_gravity_1687`). To 'prove' the theory in the book, Halley undertook the massive task of calculating the orbits of 24 historical comets. In doing so, he saw the pattern. His calculation was so precise it even accounted for the 'perturbations' (gravitational tugs) from Jupiter and Saturn, which he predicted would slightly delay the comet. He predicted its arrival for late 1758 or early 1759.

fun_facts.text_en: On Christmas Day, 1758, the comet was spotted by a German farmer and amateur astronomer, exactly as predicted. Halley (who died in 1742) was proven correct 16 years after his death, and it was hailed as the definitive triumph of the Newtonian universe.
The comet was immediately named 'Halley's Comet' in his honor. Its last visit was in 1986, and its next will be in 2061.

simple_explanation.text_en: Before Halley, people thought comets were 'one-time' omens of disasterâ€”'fireballs' thrown by God. Halley, being Newton's best friend, believed Newton's new law of gravity worked for *everything*. He thought, 'What if comets aren't fireballs, but just planets with *really* long, stretched-out orbits?' He looked at old records and saw the comets from 1531, 1607, and 1682 (all ~76 years apart) looked identical. He made a bet: 'I predict it will come back in 1758.' 50 years later, it did. Halley proved that comets are just 'ghost trains' of the solar system, and they run on a schedule.

applications.text_en: The comet's return was the first and most spectacular 'experimental proof' of Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation. It proved Newton's laws worked not just for planets, but for distant comets, too.

applications.text_en: Halley's calculation of the 'perturbations' from Jupiter and Saturn founded the science of precision 'celestial mechanics'â€”the study of complex gravitational interactions between many bodies.

impact.text_en: Halley's prediction, and its fulfillment, was the 'coronation moment' of the Scientific Revolution. Its cultural and scientific impact was unparalleled. It proved to the world that the universe was a 'clockwork mechanism', governed not by divine whims, but by unchangeable *mathematical laws* that human reason could understand and *predict*. It established the absolute authority of Newtonian physics (and 'The Enlightenment') for the next 200 years.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Isaac Newton (whose Law of Universal Gravitation was the sole theoretical tool Halley used)
Kepler (whose laws of elliptical orbits were the basis for Halley's calculations)

influenced.contribution_en: Laplace (whose 'Celestial Mechanics' was the systematic perfection of Halley's 'perturbation' calculations)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Halley used Newton's laws to transform comets from terrifying 'omens' into predictable 'clocks'.

quiz.question_en: How did Edmond Halley 'prove' that the comets of 1531, 1607, and 1682 were the same comet?
options_en: He saw a marking on the comet with a telescope
He used Newton's laws of gravity to calculate that their orbits were identical, and then predicted its return
He found they all came from the same constellation
He found an ancient manuscript from Ptolemy
quiz.explanation_en: Halley's contribution was *calculation*, not observation. He was the first to apply Newton's laws to comet orbits. He found the orbital parameters (perihelion, inclination, etc.) of these three comets were nearly identical, with the only difference being they showed up every ~76 years. He therefore predicted its return.
